Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dark Matter in Galaxy Halos
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will investigate the enigmatic "dark matter" in nearby galaxies. Dark matter does not radiate but its gravity tugs at the stars in a galaxy. Observations of such tracer stars provide clues about the dark matter. The team will use forefront facilities to study the starlight at optical wavelengths. They will focus on the faint outskirts of giant galaxies and on some just-discovered dwarf galaxies. The team will compare their observations to simulations of the dark matter in these diverse -- thus challenging -- settings. Senior team members will train junior members recruited from underrepresented groups. The team will continue its successful partnership with Science Buddies, an on-line resource for increasing K-12 science literacy.

For the giant early-type galaxies, the team will use chemodynamics to map out their dark matter distributions and to study their assembly histories. For the dwarf ultra-diffuse galaxies, the team will use spectroscopy to study their dark matter distributions and their star formation histories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nature of Dark Matter (DM) is one of the most important issues in astrophysics because DM dictates how ordinary matter clumps together to form stars and galaxies. It is generally accepted that without DM galaxies cannot form and, although the precise nature of DM is unknown, we can infer many of its characteristics by studying the starlight from present day galaxies and from their associated globular cluster (GC) systems. GCs are ancient stellar systems - stellar balls about a million times more massive than the Sun, orbiting in large numbers around galaxies of all morphological types. As such they are bright beacons that can be observed in detail even when the starlight of the galaxy to which they belong is too faint to study. Light from GCs was used to provide chemical and temporal fingerprints of their origins, thereby dating their host galaxies' epochs of formation and providing insight into the types of satellite galaxies that fell in to build up the host galaxy via hierarchical merging over cosmic time. The motions of GCs around their host galaxies reveal the spatial distribution of DM around each galaxy, which is a key input into cosmological simulations of galaxy formation. The number of GCs that orbit a galaxy is directly correlated with its total mass - the mass including stars, gas and DM.  Moreover, the motions of GCs reveal the total ?dynamical? mass of the host galaxy, which is compared to the mass inferred from the GC number count. If the galaxy starlight is bright enough, a third total mass estimate is obtained from the motions of the stars themselves as they move in the gravitational potential well of the galaxy to which they belong.  A newly discovered class of Ultra Diffuse Galaxies (UDGs) has been studied with these approaches. The origins of UDGs, which have the sizes of giant galaxies but the luminosities of dwarfs, are controversial. Are they ?failed giants?, massive galaxies that failed to form the normal quantity of stars? Or, are they dwarf galaxies that were puffed up to large sizes?  Measuring the total masses of UDGs is an important first step to answering these questions and, because their starlight is extremely faint, most UDG masses are inferred from the characteristics of their GC systems, with direct verification from the starlight achievable only for a chosen few.  Some UDGs have been found to exhibit a huge excess of DM while at least two others appear to have a complete lack of DM!  Students and postdocs were engaged in cutting-edge research on galaxies and their GCs, using project data as well as open access databases and artificial intelligence/ machine-learning tools. These tools have broad application in other areas of science, technology, medicine, business and finance.
